name: inia-geoffrensis
definition: The Amazon river dolphin is a species of toothed whale classified in the family Iniidae.
description:
The Amazon river dolphin is one of the five river dolphins and is the most famous species of the group.

The body of this mammal is long and plump, whereas the fins remind paddles by their shape.

In addition, the animal can be easily identified by having a ridge on its back instead of a dorsal fin.

The Amazon river dolphin is the largest species of river dolphin, with adult males reaching 185 kilograms in weight, and 2.5 meters in length.

Adults acquire a pink color, more prominent in males, giving it its nickname pink river dolphin.

Like other toothed whales, they have a melon, an organ that is used for bio sonar.

The Amazon river dolphin is a South American mammal, distributed across the drainage basins of the Orinoco and Amazon rivers.

They are mostly present in rivers and streams with slow current.

As the wet season comes, the water level increases, flooding surrounding forests.

During this period, the dolphins usually leave the deeper streams to swim through the trees.

Amazon River dolphins are carnivores, specifically piscivores.

Their diet usually consists of crustaceans, fish and crabs.

Except for humans, the Amazon River Dolphin does not have many predators.

However, caiman, jaguars and anacondas have been known to catch dolphins on occasions.

Currently, very little is known about the mating system of these animals.

Males display extremely aggressive behavior: because of biting and abrasion, male dolphins often damage their fins, flukes, and blowholes.

Gestation period lasts approximately 11 months.

The female dolphin normally yields a single baby with an interval of up to 5 years.

As soon as the baby is born, the mother immediately helps the youngster to come to the water surface for air.

The calf is nursed by its mother for about a year after birth, becoming independent within 2 to 3 years.

The Amazon river dolphins are typically found solitarilly as well as in pairs.

However, there have been recorded dolphin groups, consisting of up to 15 individuals.

These dolphins are most active in the early morning and late evening.

They are neither fast swimmers nor deep divers, often preferring to swim on the water surface.

The Amazon river dolphins are highly communicative animals, sometimes interacting with other dolphin species.

Rolling, lob tailing and flipper waving are common behavior among these playful animals.

Moreover, they frequently play with their logs as well as pull at underwater grass.

Also, these dolphins can often be seen playing with turtles, fish and other aquatic life forms.

facts.name: Have dorsal ridge instead of dorsal fin
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins have dorsal ridge instead of dorsal fin. Their flippers are shaped like paddles that move in a circular motion.

facts.name: Communicate using different types of clicks
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins communicate using different types of clicks and whistles.

facts.name: Diet of Amazon river dolphins
facts.value: Diet of Amazon river dolphins consists of fish, shrimps and crabs. They also eat piranhas and turtles. Amazon river dolphins are true carnivores.

facts.name: Despite being large in size
facts.value: Despite being large in size, Amazon river dolphins have couple of natural enemies. Main predators of Amazon river dolphins are caimans, large snakes and jaguars.

facts.name: Can move from rivers to ponds
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins can move from rivers to ponds and lakes during the rainy season, when rivers are flooded.

facts.name: Unlike other dolphin species
facts.value: Unlike other dolphin species, Amazon river dolphins are solitary during the most part of the year. Males and females live together when they are taking care of the offspring.

facts.name: Amazon river dolphins are very playful
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins are very playful, curious and highly intelligent creatures. These animals are able to recognize potential threats associated with humans and learn to avoid them.

facts.name: Use echolocation for hunting
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins use echolocation for hunting. They release sound which travels through the water and bounces from the objects in front of them. Returning sound carries information about size, type and speed of the object or prey in front of them.

facts.name: Neck vertebrae are loosely connected
facts.value: Neck vertebrae of Amazon river dolphins are loosely connected. This feature allows rotation of neck for 180 degrees and it facilitates finding of prey.

facts.name: Survive up to 30 years in the wild
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins can survive up to 30 years in the wild.

facts.name: Reach 2.5 meters in length
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins can reach 2.5 meters in length, but they are usually smaller. On average, Amazon river dolphins weigh between 100 and 185 kilograms.

facts.name: Pregnancy in females lasts 9 months
facts.value: Pregnancy in females lasts 9 months and ends with one baby. Baby is usually 75 centimeters long and weighs 10 kilograms. Most babies are born from July to September.

facts.name: Amazon river dolphins can be pink
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins can be pink, blue or albino (completely white due to lack of pigment) in color.

facts.name: Have small eyes and poor eyesight
facts.value: Amazon river dolphins have small eyes and poor eyesight because they live in murky waters, with low visibility.

facts.name: Sexual maturity depends on the size
facts.value: Sexual maturity depends on the size of animal. Females become sexually mature when they reach 165 centimeters length, while males become sexually mature when they reach length of 210 centimeters.

related.definition: The spinner dolphin  is a small dolphin found in off-shore tropical waters around the world.
The striped dolphin  is an extensively studied dolphin found in temperate and tropical waters of all the world's oceans.
The harbour porpoise  is one of six species of porpoise.
The Indo-Pacific finless porpoise is one of seven porpoise species.
The melon-headed whale is a small to medium sized toothed whale of the oceanic dolphin family .
The false killer whale  is an oceanic dolphin that inhabits oceans worldwide but mainly frequents tropical regions.
